page.title: 19Bonnington Power Station
page.content: Bonnington Power Station is one of the oldest power stations in Scotland and was built in 1926. It is driven by the Bonnington Falls on the River Clyde which makes it a hydro-electric power station. The station is automatic but six men keep it clean, working from 8a.m. to 4.30p.m. A man called John Day who has worked there for 42 years showed us the two turbines. The water comes from a mile up the Clyde through two big green pipes to drive the turbines. The falls have a drop of 190 ft and four times a year the power is switched off and the falls are open to the public. No back-up fuel is used and the power produced is fed into the national grid.
